title: 114_s2417
content: The "Tribal Veterans Health Care Enhancement Act" is the short title of the Act. It addresses copayments for Indian veterans receiving certain medical services. The Indian Health Care Improvement Act is amended to allow the Service to pay copayments for eligible Indian veterans receiving medical services at VA facilities. The Indian Health Care Improvement Act allows the Service to cover copayments for eligible Indian veterans receiving medical care at VA facilities. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may accept a payment from the Service under certain provisions of law. Definitions for "appropriate committees of Congress" are provided in the subsection. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may accept a payment from the Indian Health Service. Definitions for key terms such as "beneficiary of the Service" and "Director" are provided in the subsection. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Director of the Indian Health Service will enter into a memorandum of understanding to allow the Director to pay copayments owed to the VA by veterans who are beneficiaries of the Service for services rendered by the VA. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Director of the Indian Health Service will enter into a memorandum of understanding to allow the Director to pay copayments owed to the VA by veterans referred from the Service under the Purchased/Referred Care program. Factors for consideration include findings in a report, and a joint certification to Congress may exempt them from the agreement if it would decrease healthcare quality. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Director of the Indian Health Service will submit a report to Congress within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The report will detail the number of veterans benefiting from the Service, categorized by State. The aim is to prevent any decrease in healthcare quality or access for veterans and individuals receiving care from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The report to Congress will include the number of veterans who are beneficiaries of the Service and have received healthcare at a VA facility, as well as those referred to a VA facility from the Service between January 1, 2010, and December 31, 2015. Additionally, it will provide an update on efforts to streamline healthcare for veterans. The report to Congress will detail efforts by the Director to streamline healthcare for veterans who are beneficiaries of the Service and have received care at both VA and Service facilities, including any changes required under the Indian Health Care Improvement Act and barriers to efficient care provision.
